newsitem.title: UK: U.S. STOCKS IN LONDON FIRM, AWAIT WALL STREET LEAD.
newsitem.headline: U.S. STOCKS IN LONDON FIRM, AWAIT WALL STREET LEAD.

text.p: U.S. shares were generally higher following Wall Street's record finish on Thursday but trading volumes remained thin as European investors awaited more corporate earnings data and the Dow's open. "The market in
Europe is always nervous during the corporate reporting season," one market maker said. "Rising bond yields and the Dow at record levels only adds to the nervousness."
The Dow ended 38.49 points up at 6,765.37 on Thursday.
General Motors was up 3/8 from its U.S. close, at 60-3/4 following news of the 9.5 billion stock-and-debt-deal to sell its Hughes Aircraft unit to Raytheon Co.
Eastman Kodak was up 3/8 at 85-7/8 following a 4-1/4 jump in the U.S., on news that company had raised its quarterly dividend and intended to improve its cost structure.
The company also said late on Thursday that it would cut 4,000 jobs worldwide in the next 12 to 18 months.
Elsewhere, oil stocks were mostly lower, after a mixed U.S. session.
"Some analysts are starting to say oil stocks are fairly valued and may come off now after a good run," another dealer said.
Exxon was down 1/4 at 103 while Mobil eased 1/2 at 131.
Archer Daniels Midland Co, which lost 5/8 in New York, was down 1/4 at 21-5/8, after reporting lower-than-expected second quarter earnings of 0.35 per share, down from 0.41 a year ago.
High-technology issues were mostly firmer, led by Intel, up 1/2 at 142-7/8. Digital was 3/8 firmer at 37-1/4, while IBM added 1/4 at 165-3/8.
The March T-bond was up 3/32 at 110-26/32, while the S&P 500 futures contract on the Globex after hours trading system was up 0.50 at 775.75 by 1130 GMT.
